title: Ashley Albrecht, Ryan Morrell
description: The couple met five years ago through mutual friends in New York. They were married in Miami.
content: Ashley Alexandra Albrecht and Ryan Francis Morrell were married March 7 at Samsara Gardens in Miami. Angela Thomas, the bride’s sister who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 8, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, March 8, 2020.
content: An article on Page 14 about a growing number of women who direct films misstates the surname of a director. It is Janicza Bravo, not Brown.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Ting Guo, Michael Villaseñor
description: He liked her purple hair and she liked his natural silver curls.
content: Ting Ting Guo and Michael Anthony Villaseñor were married March 2 at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Joey Tai, a member of the New York City clerk’s office officiated. On March 7, members of the bride’s family led a Chinese tea ceremony, followed by another ceremony where the couple exchanged vows at the Kimpton Hotel Palomar in San Diego.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Kidding’ and ‘The Outsider’
description: Catch the season finales of Jim Carrey’s dark comedy “Kidding” on Showtime and the Stephen King adaptation “The Outsider” on HBO.
content: KIDDING 10 p.m. on Showtime. When a show is granted a second run, it faces the pressure of matching the success of its first and proving it has promise for more to come. This poignant tragicomedy, about a beloved children’s television host (Jim Carrey) who strains to keep his brand intact as his personal life crumbles, has plenty of life left in it. Last week’s episode walked us through the past, before Jeff’s son Phil died in a car accident. Season 2 wraps up on Sunday with a two-part finale, in which Jeff realizes he would be better off on his own for a while. If you have yet to give the show a try, it’s never too late to delve into the dark, imaginative world of Puppet Time — and Carrey puts on an emotional, layered performance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Anyone Who Wants a Coronavirus Test Can Have One, Trump Says. Not Quite, Says His Administration.
description: Key officials in recent days have corrected or clarified the president, who has sought to project calm as the coronavirus continues to spread in the United States.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration on Saturday continued sending contradictory signals about its response to the coronavirus, as a top federal health official appeared to walk back President Trump’s claim that “anyone who wants a test can get a test.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nazanin Lankarani
title: Cartier to Celebrate Women at the Expo 2020 in Dubai
description: “We will not be talking about products,” the house’s president said.
content: When the Expo 2020 opens in Dubai, scheduled Oct. 20, Cartier intends to welcome visitors to the international fair in its own stand-alone pavilion dedicated to women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | March 9, 2020
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: Students
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Ah, Tea. So Relaxing. But Its History Is Another Story.
description: A room at the Metropolitan Museum of Art tells the story of tea and politics, from China to Britain and that “party” in Boston.
content: This article is part of our latest Museums special section, which focuses on the intersection of art and politics.
source.name: The New York Times

title: In U.S., Cases of Coronavirus Cross 500, and Deaths Rise to 22
description: A top U.S. health official says regional lockdowns are possible and warns the most vulnerable against travel as a 19th person dies in Washington State.

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: ‘Onward’ Tops Box Office, but Falls Short for Pixar
description: “Onward” brought in an estimated $40 million in domestic ticket sales, a relatively weak opening by Pixar standards.
content: In “Onward,” the latest animated feature from Pixar, two elf brothers cast a magic spell that half-succeeds: They bring their dead father back to life, but only from the waist down, as a pair of sentient pants and shoes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: 1 Killed and 17 Wounded in Biker Clubs Shooting, Police Say
description: The shooting in Cleveland happened on Saturday night after a fight broke out at a party, and some people left then later returned, firing on attendees, officials said.
content: A man was killed and 17 other people were wounded after gunfire erupted at a party involving multiple motorcycle clubs on Saturday night in Cleveland, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall and Katie Van Syckle
title: Coronavirus Bandits? 2 Armed Men in Surgical Masks Rob Racetrack
description: They stole $200,000 to $270,000 from the Aqueduct Racetrack in Queens, officials said.
content: Three workers at the Aqueduct Racetrack in Queens were transporting hundreds of thousands in dollars in cash on Saturday night when they were accosted by two gunmen, the police said. The thieves made off with more than $200,000, aided in part by surgical masks they wore to conceal their identities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Sanders Is Behind With Black Voters. He Didn’t Fix That in Flint.
description: An event in Michigan was billed as an opportunity for the senator to make his case directly to black voters, who have broken strongly for Joe Biden. It didn’t work out that way.
content: FLINT, Mich. — Cornel West pleaded with his “own black people” to support Senator Bernie Sanders.
source.name: The New York Times

title: In U.S., Cases of Coronavirus Cross 500, and Deaths Rise to 22
description: A top U.S. health official says regional lockdowns are possible and warns the most vulnerable against travel as a 19th person dies in Washington State.
content: [This briefing has ended. Read the latest updates on the coronavirus epidemic here.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard A. Friedman
title: The Best Response to the Coronavirus? Altruism, Not Panic
description: The impulse to secure your safety is understandable but counterproductive.
content: Are you fearful about catching the coronavirus? Are you anxious about whether you’re properly prepared for its arrival? You’re in good company.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Five Short Films by Women, About Women
description: Op-Docs for International Women’s Day.
content: After going on the pill at age 11 for painful endometriosis, a young woman says, “I deserve birth control, but I also deserve better birth control.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Coronavirus, Mount Everest, International Women’s Day: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.

author: By Peter Baker
title: For Trump, Coronavirus Proves to Be an Enemy He Can’t Tweet Away
description: A president who is at his strongest politically when he has a human target to attack has found it harder to confront a growing outbreak that has rattled the country.
content: PALM BEACH, Fla. — Defending against criticism of his handling of the coronavirus, President Trump suggested the other day that he could hardly have been expected to be ready for such an unexpected crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Gabriella Schwarz, Benjamin Wasserman
description: The couple first saw each other in 2014 while working in the Palo Alto, Calif., office of Flipboard.
content: Gabriella Anna Schwarz and Benjamin Daniel Wasserman were married March 7 at Central Synagogue in Manhattan. Rabbi Angela Warnick Buchdahl officiated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laurel Graeber
title: The Climate Changes Before Your Eyes
description: The American Museum of Natural History focuses on science, not politics, in its display of an environmentally challenged planet.
content: This article is part of our latest Museums special section, which focuses on the intersection of art and politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Schwartz
title: Worlds of Oppression Are Interwoven in a New York Show
description: An exhibition by Jonathan Horowitz at the Jewish Museum comes in response to rising episodes of anti-Semitism, but doesn’t stop there.
content: This article is part of our latest Museums special section, which focuses on the intersection of art and politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: Nursing Home Hit by Coronavirus Says 70 Workers Are Sick
description: As a federal team arrived to help, a spokesman for the Kirkland, Wash., center said 70 staff members were out with symptoms that resembled coronavirus.
content: SEATTLE — A week after a deadly coronavirus outbreak was reported inside a nursing home in the Seattle suburbs, officials from the long term care center said on Saturday that 70 staff members were out sick with symptoms resembling coronavirus and six residents were also ill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Coronavirus in Connecticut: Governor Announces First Case of Resident
description: The patient, who lives in Wilton, is 40 to 50 years of age.
content: Connecticut has its first case of coronavirus involving a resident, Gov. Ned Lamont said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Phoebe Lett
title: Podcasts Worth a Listen: ‘Fiasco,’ ‘Unwell,’ ‘In Those Genes’
description: A fictitious Kevin Bacon (played by Kevin Bacon), an improvised space opera and a Midwestern gothic horror story are audio dramas you might want to add to your queue.
content: As the country hurtles toward the election in November, politically minded podcasts are increasingly popping up in our feeds. Members of Congress are employing the medium as a personal soap box for their constituents. Representative Dan Crenshaw of Texas (“Hold These Truths”) and Representative James E. Clyburn of South Carolina (“Clyburn Chronicles”) began their shows this year, and Senator Ted Cruz’s erratically released impeachment podcast (“Verdict With Ted Cruz”) briefly topped Apple Podcast’s charts. And last month it was announced that Hillary Clinton would be starting her own iHeartRadio podcast this spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Daniel Craig Hosts ‘S.N.L.,’ but Elizabeth Warren Steals the Show
description: The senator played herself in a surprise appearance in an episode that featured the Weeknd as the musical guest.
content: It started out familiar: a “Saturday Night Live” sketch centered on impersonations of political figures. But then it was rescued by something even more familiar: the show’s ability to wrangle real-life politicians to come on the show during an election season — which in this case yielded Senator Elizabeth Warren, who announced on Thursday that she was exiting the race for the Democratic presidential nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: Girl With Disabilities Sexually Abused and Raped on School Bus, Lawsuit Says
description: Two other students with special needs abused the girl over a 17-day period, and the driver did not report it until after the girl was raped, court papers say.
content: A 14-year-old girl with developmental disabilities was sexually abused for several consecutive days and raped by students on her school bus without intervention by the driver, according to a lawsuit filed last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Manchester United Beats City, Turning the Tables for a Day
description: Manchester United has become a club trained to expect the worst. On Sunday, thanks to Bruno Fernandes and Anthony Martial, it was at its best again.
content: MANCHESTER, England — For a while on derby day, Old Trafford was a quiet, apprehensive sort of a place. On the field, Manchester City drew its pretty, disorienting patterns. In the stands, Manchester United’s fans watched on in truculent silence, fretting and murmuring and worrying about what was to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: An Olympic Doctor Discusses the Effect of the Coronavirus on Sports
description: Though the Summer Games in Tokyo are expected to go on as scheduled, “it is a dynamically changing situation,” said Jonathan Finnoff, the new chief medical officer for Team U.S.A.
content: Jonathan Finnoff became the chief medical officer of the United States Olympic and Paralympic Committee in January, taking on a job that typically focuses on the sports-related injuries and risks of athletes who represent the country at international competitions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Apuzzo, Motoko Rich and David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Failures on the Diamond Princess Shadow Another Cruise Ship Outbreak
description: An alert about a coronavirus infection sat in an unmonitored inbox. A cruise doctor saw “no point” in disinfecting the ship. And Japan disregarded medical guidelines to contain an outbreak.
content: The email to Princess Cruises was peppered with typos and awkward grammar, but the warning was unmistakable. An 80-year-old passenger had tested positive for the new coronavirus after getting off the Diamond Princess cruise ship in Hong Kong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss and Stanley Reed
title: Oil Prices Dive as Saudi Arabia Takes Aim at Russian Production
description: Russia on Friday rejected an agreement with OPEC on cuts in oil supplies to bolster prices.
content: Saudi Arabia slashed its export oil prices over the weekend in what is likely to be the start of a price war aimed at Russia but with potentially devastating repercussions for Russia’s ally Venezuela, Saudi Arabia’s enemy Iran and even American oil companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon, Ellen Barry and Karen Weise
title: Forfeited Games and Virtual Learning: Coronavirus Shuts Down Schools
description: As the virus continues to spread across the country, schools are closing their doors in an effort to protect their students.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — After months of training and competition, the girls’ soccer team at Lowell High School in San Francisco could taste another title.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz and Emma Bubola
title: On Day 1 of Broad Lockdown, a Debate Arises: Can Italians Follow the Rules?
description: Italy’s prime minister implored the public to cooperate in the largest clampdown against the coronavirus in the Western world. “We are the new Wuhan,” said one Milan resident.
content: ROME — Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte ended his 2:15 a.m. news conference to announce the extraordinary lockdown of Italy’s north with a plea that other heads of state may not have felt compelled to make.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Blair Warner, Thomas Ciszek
description: The couple, who met two years ago, are marrying on the beach in Santa Monica, Calif.
content: Blair Christine Warner and Thomas Ryan Ciszek are to be married March 8 near Tower 24 on the beach in Santa Monica, Calif. Chris Robinson, a Universal Life minister, is to officiate. On May 18, the couple are to take part in a religious ceremony at St. Peter’s Basilica in Vatican City. Msgr. Steve Carlson, a friend of the groom’s family, is to perform the ceremony.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Ellen Gray, Antoine Ibrahim
description: The couple met in August 2016 at the Barclay’s, a PGA Tour event, in Bethpage, N.Y.
content: Ellen Grace Gray and Antoine Fahmy Ibrahim were married March 7 at the Church of our Saviour in Manhattan. Msgr. Kevin Sullivan performed the ceremony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: CPAC Attendee Has the Coronavirus, Officials Say
description: The Conservative Political Action Conference was attended last week by President Trump, Vice President Mike Pence and other administration officials.
content: An attendee of a conservative conference where President Trump and Vice President Mike Pence spoke last week has tested positive for the coronavirus, according to the event’s organizer.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Catherine Doyle, Hollis Callaway
description: The couple met in 2018 at Church, a bar in Atlanta.
content: Catherine Luisa Doyle and Hollis Boynton Callaway were married March 7 at the Yellowstone Club, a ski and golf resort in Big Sky, Mont. The Rev. Frank Wright, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Sarah Schiear, Jared Spiegel
description: The couple met in 2016 when Mrs. Spiegel was looking for a lawyer while she was starting her company, and a networking contact recommended Mr. Spiegel.
content: Sarah Ashley Schiear and Jared Brett Spiegel were married March 7 at Race & Religious, a rental property in New Orleans. Rabbi Erdheim officiated.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Was on the F Train Headed to an Afternoon Doctor’s Appointment’
description: A little subway reading, walking Manhattan after Sandy and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Fourth Time’s the Charm? Mark Meadows Takes Over Trump’s White House
description: Mr. Meadows, a retiring Republican congressman from North Carolina and one of President Trump’s most ardent defenders, becomes the latest chief of staff for a mercurial president who dispatched the previous three after they fell out of favor.
content: PALM BEACH, Fla. — One day last month, Mark Meadows went on Fox News to defend President Trump’s decision to begin purging the government of officials perceived to be disloyal to him. “Part of his administration is trying to defeat the Trump agenda,” Mr. Meadows declared.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Jaffa Panken, Josh Stanton
description: The couple met in 2008 at a Flaming Lips concert in Philadelphia.
content: Jaffa Loren Panken and Herbert Joshua Stanton were married March 7 at King Plow Arts Center in Atlanta. Rabbi Laurence Rosenthal officiated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Start off strong with a creamy turmeric pasta, move into a Tater Tot hot dish, and round out Friday with chicken paprikash.
content: Good morning. Where does the time go? We’ve lost an hour today, and that’s grand for those who love evening sunlight, but it may have left you logy and confused this morning. Accordingly, we’ve assembled a huge collection of ridiculously easy recipes for the first day of daylight saving time. For dinner tonight, out of that collection, I’m thinking sheet-pan harissa salmon with potatoes and citrus (above), but you may find your own bliss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Gyms and Coronavirus: What Are the Risks?
description: Sweat cannot transmit the virus but high-contact surfaces, such as barbells, can pose a problem, a doctor said.
content: It’s not the kind of thing you want to think about while you’re in child’s pose in yoga class, when your nose is close to the mat, but after hearing how you should stop touching your face to guard against the coronavirus, you might wonder: What are the risks of transmission while working out at a gym?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penn Bullock and Elijah Walker
title: Coronavirus, Mick Mulvaney, Black Hole: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carolyn Shapiro
title: Using History to Provide a Lens Into Today’s Politics
description: Vermont’s Rokeby Museum has both exposed and experienced the effects of racism at its preserved historic site on a former sheep farm.
content: This article is part of our latest Museums special section, which focuses on the intersection of art and politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: Coronavirus Sends Markets Into a Panic
description: The illness is hitting the U.S. economy, and it's just getting started.
content: I coughed on the subway the other day and almost caused a stampede. Which is a fitting metaphor for the stock market this past week, except that the stampede really happened. Given the extraordinary circumstances, we’re dedicating most of today’s newsletter to the economic effects of the coronavirus outbreak so far, along with the usual top stories in business and tech for the week ahead. Stay safe, everyone. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Unrelenting Space Jams of Tame Impala
description: How has Kevin Parker built and sustained his successful psych-rock project — and where will he head next?
content: After a five year quasi-hiatus, the psychedelic etherealist outfit Tame Impala has returned with a new album, “The Slow Rush.” Tame Impala is actually just one man: Kevin Parker, an Australian singer-songwriter and multi-instrumentalist who makes music in isolation, and who has had a sui generis kind of success in the last decade reviving a strain of rock not much heralded since the 1960s and 1970s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Eblen
title: In 1918, It Wasn’t the Coronavirus. It Was the Flu.
description: The “Spanish flu” pandemic, the subject of a new, ongoing exhibit at the Mütter Museum, killed tens of millions of people worldwide.
content: This article is part of our latest Museums special section, which focuses on the intersection of art and politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Astead W. Herndon
title: Bernie Sanders Won Michigan in 2016. Tuesday’s Primary Looks Much Tougher.
description: Four years ago, Mr. Sanders drew support from some voters who didn’t like Hillary Clinton. Joe Biden is poised to do well with black Democrats and college-educated white voters.
content: DETROIT — Four years ago, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont scored an upset win over Hillary Clinton in the Michigan Democratic primary, reviving his insurgent candidacy one week after his political prospects dimmed because of Super Tuesday losses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jose Solís
title: Review: Notes of Joy and Fear Fill This ‘Fandango’
description: “Fandango for Butterflies (and Coyotes),” an En Garde Arts production, invites audiences to experience a musical gathering popular among immigrants, this one under the threat of a raid.
content: As the festive notes of a guitar fill the room, and smartly dressed men and women set up towers of tamales that threaten to overwhelm their containers, it feels for a moment as if nothing could go wrong in the world of Andrea Thome’s rapturous “Fandango for Butterflies (and Coyotes).”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel, Davey Alba and Raymond Zhong
title: Surge of Virus Misinformation Stumps Facebook and Twitter
description: Secret labs. Magic cures. Government plots. Despite efforts by social media companies to stop it, false information about the coronavirus is proliferating around the world.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — First, there were conspiratorial whispers on social media that the coronavirus had been cooked up in a secret government lab in China. Then there were bogus medicines: gels, liquids and powders that immunized against the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corina Knoll
title: New York in the Age of Coronavirus
description: As the number of cases climbs, a pall of anxiety has descended on the city.
content: It was not the grand affair of their dreams. She wore a borrowed maxi skirt. He felt the absence of his sister and grandmother. They swapped mood rings bought days earlier on Canal Street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: What José Parlá, JR and Kunle Martins Learned from Graffiti
description: For Parlá, it’s a mode of aesthetic innovation; for JR, it’s a jumping-off point and a pretense; for Martins, it’s a way to connect past and present.
content: It’s been refreshing to see the recent bursts of full-car subway graffiti in New York, a kaleidoscopic jolt of anarchy that recalls the city before glass towers, before subway countdown clocks, before the street-art gallery at Hudson Yards. The huffing and puffing that greeted these trains also served as a reminder that graffiti is both a disruptive aesthetic choice and a disruptive social practice — where it happens is just as crucial as what it looks like.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Kaplan and Jonathan Martin
title: Kamala Harris Endorses Joe Biden for President
description: Ms. Harris, who ended her own presidential campaign in December, is the latest in a parade of prominent Democrats to throw their support behind Mr. Biden.
content: Senator Kamala Harris of California endorsed former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. for president on Sunday, becoming the latest of his formal rivals for the Democratic nomination to get behind his presidential bid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Europe, With Eye on Italy Coronavirus Quarantine, Plans Next Moves
description: Italy’s decision to quarantine a quarter of its population is sending tremors through Europe’s economy and testing the bloc’s unity.
content: LONDON — Italy’s sweeping lockdown of its north reverberated through Europe on Sunday, fueling fears of similarly draconian measures from London to Berlin, as officials grappled with how to slow the rapid-fire spread of the coronavirus in several of the world’s most open and democratic societies.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Anti-Semitism Affects All Jews, Not Just the Orthodox
description: A deputy commissioner at the New York City Commission on Human Rights writes about the need to unite to fight anti-Semitism. Also: A legacy of Pete Buttigieg; the national security adviser and the president.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: What It Means to Be #NashvilleStrong
description: The tornadoes that tore through Middle Tennessee felt like the apocalypse. But people here had other plans.
content: NASHVILLE — My husband and I would’ve slept through the tornado that hit Nashville in the middle of the night last week, but our nocturnal middle son woke us up to say his phone had just issued a tornado warning. The wind was hardly blowing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meir Soloveichik
title: Queen Esther, a Hero for Our Time
description: A paradox of Jewish fragility and heroism.
content: A perplexing paradox lies at the heart of Purim, the holiday celebrated this week by Jews around the world. No day is more associated with Jewish joy; yet rightly understood the scriptural source of our celebration — the biblical book of Esther — proclaims a terrifying teaching.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Judge Orders Medical Panel to Evaluate Tortured Guantánamo Prisoner
description: For the first time, a federal court is requiring the United States military to allow American and foreign doctors to assess a mentally ill prisoner at Guantánamo Bay.
content: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger, Eric Schmitt and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: A Secret Accord With the Taliban: When and How the U.S. Would Leave Afghanistan
description: The Taliban have read the secret annexes of the recently signed peace deal. But most Americans haven’t, nor have many of their elected representatives.
content: WASHINGTON — In a secure facility underneath the Capitol, members of Congress stopped by all last week to review two classified annexes to the Afghan peace accord with the Taliban that set the criteria for a critical element of the agreement: What constitutes enough “peace” for the United States to withdraw its forces?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Pamela Chaliff, Alexander Margolis
description: The couple met at Columbia, where each received an M.B.A.
content: Pamela Lauren Chaliff and Alexander Smithberg Margolis were married March 7 at the Foundry at Puritan Mill, an events space in Atlanta. Rabbi Spike Anderson officiated.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Kristen McCannon, Pavan Krishnamurthy
description: The couple met at Georgetown, from which each received a law degree, the groom cum laude.
content: Kristen Elizabeth McCannon and Capt. Pavan Shridhar Krishnamurthy were married March 7 at the Adolphus Hotel in Dallas. Chandramouli Srinivasan, a Hindu priest, led an interfaith ceremony incorporating both Hindu and Christian wedding traditions, with Sydney Menees, a Universal Life minister and friend of the couple, taking part.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Meng Hsieh, Andrew Shubin
description: The couple met a decade ago at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., as postbaccalaureate research fellows.
content: Dr. Meng-Lun Hsieh and Dr. Andrew Dean Shubin were married March 7 at the Warwick Melrose Hotel in Dallas. The Rev. Beth Dana, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Trump Welcomes Brazil’s Bolsonaro but Leaves Tariffs on the Table
description: The president hosted President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil at his Florida estate amid unresolved tension over possible steel and iron levies.
content: PALM BEACH, Fla. — President Trump hosted President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil for a festive dinner at his Florida estate on Saturday but refused to rule out steel and iron tariffs that have created tension in the relationship between the two most populous countries of the Western Hemisphere.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Returning From the Front Lines to Find Jobs Ill-Suited to Their Training
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 8, 2020.
content: “These people have about $1 million of training that the government has put into them. But they don’t have one credit toward a professional degree, and they end up being turned down for jobs delivering dry cleaning.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilarie M. Sheets
title: Feminists Arm Themselves With Art
description: As the U.S. election approaches, feminism takes center stage at scores of art institutions across the country.
content: This article is part of our latest Museums special section, which focuses on the intersection of art and politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ray Mark Rinaldi
title: Bringing Human Migration Closer to Home
description: As a global refugee crisis sped up and spread out, curators at a New Mexico museum spent two years reshaping a show about people on the move.
content: This article is part of our latest Museums special section, which focuses on the intersection of art and politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Nayeri
title: As Tensions Rise With Iran, So Does Interest in Art It Inspired
description: This year, several museums in the United States will feature works by Iranian artists in exile.
content: LONDON — The Iranian artist Shirazeh Houshiary works out of a luminous studio in a leafy corner of southwest London. Her misty abstract paintings evoke the galaxy, the cosmos, the afterlife. To make them, she floods the canvas with water, pours pigment over it and draws tiny marks over the dried surface.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denise Grady
title: Not His First Epidemic: Dr. Anthony Fauci Sticks to the Facts
description: Where politicians fumble and other government health officials step back, he steps up to explain.
content: Dr. Anthony Fauci, the nation’s leading expert on infectious diseases, is widely respected for his ability to explain science without talking down to his audience — and lately, for managing to correct the president’s pronouncements without saying he is wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell
title: Where Mermaids Play, a Nasty Water Fight
description: Nestlé wants to draw more spring water from a northern Florida site owned by a local family — but environmentalists are pushing back.
content: HIGH SPRINGS, Fla. — One by one, the mermaids dived into the water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Review: An Astute Choreographer Stumbles (and Rises) to Hope
description: The Belfast artist Oona Doherty portrays working-class men in her marvelous piece at the 92nd Street Y.
content: Oona Doherty’s entrance would have been better had it been a surprise; it wasn’t, but it was still a doozy. This contemporary choreographer and performer from Belfast is astonishing — not merely raw, as she is often described, but exactingly articulate. She is in possession of a body with as much flexibility as her mind, as was revealed in her arresting exploration of the young men of her hometown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Jesse Jackson Endorses Bernie Sanders
description: The endorsement by the longtime civil rights activist and former presidential candidate came as Mr. Sanders hopes to rally black voters in Michigan’s crucial primary election.
content: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. — The Rev. Jesse Jackson endorsed Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont for president on Sunday, offering support that the senator and his team hope will rally black voters to their side ahead of a make-or-break Democratic primary race in Michigan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: For U.S. Women, a Narrow Victory and a Growing Divide
description: A late goal by Julie Ertz against Spain capped a weekend in which the women’s soccer team found itself in a new spat with U.S. Soccer over equal pay.
content: HARRISON, N.J. — One goal separated the United States women’s soccer team and Spain on Sunday. The distance between the American players and the United States Soccer Federation, however, apparently remains incalculable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: What a Robber Hopes to Get
description: John Lampkin weighs in.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — We last saw the constructor John Lampkin in 2018, and he’s back with a puzzle that might require some heavy lifting. I hope you’re in good shape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Thomas Piketty Turns Marx on His Head
description: Piketty’s latest book, “Capital and Ideology,” takes a global overview to inequality and other pressing economic issues of our time.
content: CAPITAL AND IDEOLOGY By Thomas Piketty
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kai Schultz and Bhadra Sharma
title: After Deadly Jam on Everest, Nepal Delays New Safety Rules
description: The country said it would toughen regulations after several climbers died last year. But the rules will not go into effect this spring, and climbers want to know why.
content: NEW DELHI — The images shocked and angered the world: hundreds of climbers trapped near Mount Everest’s summit, hooked to a single safety line on a ridge with a several-thousand-foot drop, their oxygen cylinders emptying until a few people died from exposure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Steyer
title: Tom Steyer: What I Learned While Running for President
description: The establishment has failed many hard-working people. If we don’t call it out, nothing will change.
content: I love meeting Americans. Before I ran for president, I had the opportunity to meet people across the country while fighting climate change, registering young people and working to impeach President Donald Trump. I loved hearing their stories and learning about their lives. Some — a lot — of their stories were harrowing. Many felt disconnected and left behind by the political establishment and elites in New York and Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: You Can’t Gaslight a Virus
description: President Trump’s usual political tricks won’t work now.
content: In the Donald Trump era, Democrats and Republicans generally live with two completely different concepts of reality. Their views of Trump, his competence and character, could hardly be more different.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Simple Reason the Left Won’t Stop Losing
description: Progressives need to care more about winning.
content: How did the political left squander the opportunity that was the 2020 primary campaign?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Dixon
title: Before the Clyburn Endorsement, an Elderly Church Usher With a Question
description: Jannie Jones is the 76-year-old woman who had to know who Representative James Clyburn was voting for in the South Carolina primary. Did her question change the Democratic presidential race?
content: HOPKINS, S.C. — Whether a simple question from an elderly church parishioner persuaded Representative James Clyburn to make his seismic endorsement of Joe Biden before the South Carolina primary will probably be known only by Mr. Clyburn himself.
source.name: The New York Times
